title: SOIL ORGANIC CARBON SEQUESTRATION IN JATROPHA CURCAS SYSTEMS IN BURKINA FASO
text:
The cultivation of the biofuel crop Jatropha curcas L. in Burkina Faso may contribute to ameliorating the soil fertility of severely declining cropland through increased organic matter input and erosion control. This study addresses the potential for the soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in traditional and newly introduced J. curcas production systems. Five prevailing systems included interplanting with annual crops, intensely managed monoculture plantations, afforestation of abandoned cropland, plantings along contour stone walls, and traditional living fences.

The SOC was analyzed in 20 paired sites of 1-to 4-year-old J. curcas plantings and adjacent cropland. Paired sites with living fences involved a longer chronosequence with 15-and 20-year-old plantings. Additionally, the contribution of J. curcas to SOC sequestration was investigated by comparing the 13 C signature of the C inputs in four J. curcas sites with that of sorghum cropping.

Linear regression analysis did not reveal a clear trend of SOC dynamics over time for the short-term chronosequences, nor could the isotopic tracer technique prove a contribution of 4-year-old J. curcas trees to the SOC stock. The 20-year chronosequence of J. curcas living fences exhibited a significant SOC increase of 62 ± 23 g m À2 y À1 . Considering soil coverage of 1,200 m 2 ha À1 by living fences (400-m hedge with a width of 3 m), 1.5 Mg SOC was sequestered. Also, changes in δ 13 C values indicated a contribution of C 3 -derived C to the SOC stock. These findings on traditional J. curcas systems indicate the potential of this biofuel crop for improving cropland soil fertility in the long run.

Soil organic carbon (SOC) plays a vital role in soil-based environmental services, soil fertility, and the productivity of an ecosystem (Vlek, 2005; Bationo et al., 2006) . In West Africa, only little organic material is left in annual cropping systems for mulching because of low productivity levels, biomass burning in the field, livestock grazing, and biomass use for energy purposes or as construction material (Tiessen et al., 1998; Bationo et al., 2006) . On the other hand, soil carbon loss is accelerated by microbe-induced, termiteinduced, and temperature-induced rapid mineralization and decomposition rates of organic material and by leaching and erosion (Batjes, 2001) . The SOC concentrations in West African soils, inherently low in fertility and under increasing anthropogenic pressure, range only between 1 and 8 g kg À1 (Bationo et al., 2006) .

The shrub species Jatropha curcas L. has been recently introduced as a low-maintenance biofuel crop with cultivation hotspots in India, Zambia, Madagascar, Tanzania, Brazil, Mexico, and Ghana (Gao et al., 2011) , on the basis of its claimed potential to increase energy security while contributing to land rehabilitation (Francis et al., 2005; Jongschaap et al., 2007) and mitigation of CO 2 emissions. In Burkina Faso, where declining soil fertility represents a main threat to agricultural production (Vlek et al., 2008) , the contribution of J. curcas cultivation to soil amelioration through increased residue inputs and erosion control could be significant. However, scientific evidence on land reclamation by J. curcas is scarce (Gasparatos et al., 2012) . Experiments carried out so far show evidence of improved soil structure and potential for C sequestration in degraded soils in a 30-month-old J. curcas plantation (Ogunwole et al., 2008) and increased soil-C stocks in J. curcas hedgerows as opposed to neighboring fields (Soulama, 2008) . Long-term soil-C sequestration rates of J. curcas systems are not known.

Studies of long-term changes in soil C in the same location are rarely feasible because of the long-term follow-up required. Therefore, comparisons of soils under plantations with those under previous land use and under plantations of different ages are valuable methods for the detection of SOC change due to afforestation. The latter "space-for-time substitution" approach implies a soil chronosequence as a series of soils that develop in similar geological positions with comparable site factors except plantation age [Jenny (1980) cited in Richter & Markewitz, 2001] . Stable C isotope studies can furthermore help to detect subtle SOC changes due to the contribution of trees to soil organic matter in systems where the 13 C signature of the C inputs from afforested plots (C 3 plants) is different from the 13 C signature of the previous land use with C 4 plants (Nyberg & Högberg, 1995; del Galdo et al., 2003) . Our study aimed to quantify the SOC dynamics in J. curcas systems as opposed to annually cultivated cropland (i) by means of comparing paired J. curcas-cropland sites in a chronosequence approach and (ii) through application of the 13 C natural abundance technique, where the land-use history allowed 13 C discrimination.

On the basis of an inventory of J. curcas cultivation systems in Burkina Faso (Hallensleben, 2011) , soil samples were collected in five existing systems (Figure 1 ).

In south-western Burkina Faso, in the Sudanian agroecological zone (AEZ), J. curcas was introduced in small-scale, lowinput intercropping systems in 2007, including annual crops, and in larger-scale, more intensely managed plantations. These sites were predominantly characterized by shallow (53 ± 7 cm) ferric lixisols, with sandy loamy texture in the topsoil and clay content increasing with depth (see Appendix S1 of the supporting information). Afforestation in the south-west also occurred on very shallow (<40 cm) leptosols and endoplinthic ferric lixisols containing over 20% of ferruginous gravel. Sandy loamy in upper horizons and more clayey with depth, these soils are particularly poor in plant-available phosphorus (P) and potassium (K) and, because of low productivity, abandoned from agricultural activities several years before J. curcas planting. Within the Sudano-Sahelian AEZ, living fences of J. curcas have been traditionally planted to protect farm fields from animals. The hedges contain J. curcas shrubs of varying age (due to self-propagation), growing on 120+-cm deep lixisols with a sandy or silt-loamy texture. Further to the north, in the Sahelian AEZ, J. curcas has been planted since 2008 along the stone walls established against wind and water erosion. This area is characterized by >100-cm deep cambisols, clay-loamy in texture with clay content increasing in deeper horizons.

The average observed soil bulk density over all sites lies between 1•33 and 1•53 g cm À3 , typically increasing with depth. The soils are moderately to slightly acidic (pH 5•9-6•3) and are very low in plant-available P (2•2 ± 0•7 ppm) and low in plantavailable K (28 ± 4•9 ppm) (BUNASOL, 1990) . Total nitrogen (N) and C concentrations, ranging between 0•06% and 0•08% and between 0•76% and 1•04%, respectively, and decreasing with depth, also reflect poor soil fertility. The C/N ratio averaged 13•8 ± 0•7 (Appendix S1).

At 20 J. curcas sites, soil pits between the tree rows were dug to the bedrock or to a maximum depth of 120 cm. The soil profiles were investigated and classified on the basis of the international World Reference Base for Soil Resources (WRB, 1998) . In each of the horizons, three undisturbed soil cores were extracted for the determination of bulk density. Samples were also collected in 0-10, 10-20, 20-40, 40-60, Figure 1 . Location of 20 paired Jatropha curcas-cropland sample sites in Burkina Faso. This figure is available in color online at wileyonlinelibrary.com/journal/ldr. and 60-100 cm soil layers for measuring SOC. Additionally, soils for the SOC analysis were sampled with a soil auger to a maximum depth of 60 cm according to the microsite sampling approach (Ellert et al., 2001) . The restriction of the sampling points to small microsites minimizes lateral variability and increases the precision in determining temporal changes in soil carbon (Ellert et al., 2001) . Thus, in two microsites (2 m × 2 m) per plantation, samples were collected at three points with an increasing distance from the tree stem (40, 120, and 200 cm) and bulked according to the sampling depth. This approach also aimed to account for differences in SOC caused by spatially variable rooting and leaf-fall patterns of J. curcas shrubs.

As reference sites, croplands in the immediate proximity of the J. curcas systems were sampled to represent the previous land use. These sites cropped with cotton, maize, sorghum, millet, and legumes (Appendix S1) were also sampled with a soil auger in two microsites to a maximum depth of 60 cm. However, soil auger sampling beyond 40-cm soil depth was hardly possible because of compacted or gravelly soil. The reference cropping sites next to contour hedges were protected by stone walls. The abandoned croplands in the vicinity of afforestation sites were not sampled because J. curcas plants survived poorly there; hence, no SOC accrual was expected. All samples were collected in the beginning of the dry period in October and November of 2010 and 2011.

Short-term soil chronosequences were selected for introduced J. curcas systems in south-western Burkina Faso, covering previous land use (cropland) and plantations aged 1, 2, 3, and 4 years (Appendix S1). For traditional living fence systems in central Burkina Faso, the long-term effect of J. curcas could be investigated in a chronosequence of two cropland sites, representing year 0, and two J. curcas living fences aged 15 and 20 years.

By using the mass balance of stable 13 C isotope contents, the relative contribution of the new agroforestry system to SOC can be detected (Balesdent & Mariotti, 1987) . To this end, topsoil (0-20 cm) and plant (leaf) samples from four sites where J. curcas was established on land formerly cropped with sorghum were analyzed with respect to their 13 C signature (expressed as δ 13 C). Adjacent sorghum-cropped sites, representing the situation before afforestation, were also analyzed for δ 13 C. The proportion of newly derived C from J. curcas plots f new was calculated according to the mass balance equation (del Galdo et al., 2003; Christensen et al., 2011) :

f new ¼ δ new À δ old δ veg À δ old

Where: δ new is δ 13 C of J. curcas, δ old is that of the reference sorghum soil, and δ veg is that of J. curcas leaves.

Total soil carbon and total SOC concentrations were analyzed by dry combustion with a EuroEA Elemental Analyzer. For SOC analysis, the soil was treated with 20% HCl beforehand. The analysis of δ 13 C was performed using a mass spectrometer (SerCon "Callisto CF-IRMS"). Prior to the analyses, all samples were dried at 103 °C for 24 h and ground to pass a 0•2-mm sieve. Soil bulk density (ρ b ) was computed as the ratio of water and gravel content corrected mass to volume (g cm À3 ). The SOC concentration (%) was converted to C stock (C t , Mg ha À1 ) for a fixed soil depth increment d (0-10, 10-20, 20-40, and 40-60 cm):

C t ¼ SOC • ρ b •d

Carbon stocks for the entire soil profiles were calculated by summing up the C stocks of individual layers down to the bedrock. Considering that ρ b can change over time because of crop choice and soil tillage, Ellert et al. (2001) recommended relating the SOC content to the unit of mass rather than volume. To account for unequal soil masses or densities among the sites, SOC was calculated in successive layers of a soil mass corresponding approximately to the soil mass of the depth increments (~14 g cm À2 for 10-cm increment). The thickness of the additional soil layer (T add ) required to attain the equivalent soil mass (M equiv ) was then computed according to the equivalent soil mass calculation proposed by Ellert et al. (2001) :

T add ¼ M equiv À M layer ρ b

with M layer as the actual soil mass of a 10-cm increment.

Statistical analyses were performed using STATA (12•0). All datasets were checked for normal distribution and homogeneity of variance. Least-square linear regression models were tested for significance. In case of overall significant results, differences between means were tested by pairwise comparison with Bonferroni adjustment. For the comparison among the cultivation systems, regression analyses were adjusted for nested design (J. curcas plantations nested in system).

The analyses were performed at p = 0•05 significance level. Mean values ± standard error (adjusted for nested design) are reported except when indicated otherwise.

Soil Organic Carbon in Jatropha curcas and Cropping Sites The SOC stock to 60-cm soil depth ranged from 33 to 66 t ha À1 (50 ± 7•5) over all cropland and J. curcas sites with ~40% of the C residing in the top 20 cm. SOC made up 97 ± 0•7% of the total C pool with no significant variation among the systems. Average SOC concentrations lay between 0•73% and 1•01% across all sites and depths. Three-factorial linear regression showed significant overall effects of the system (for 0-20 cm horizon) and depth factors (Table I ) and their interactions (p < 0•001) on SOC concentrations. The inclusion of the age factor in the overall regression model did not show interpretable results because of the unbalanced data distribution (Appendix S1).

Over all sites and systems, SOC concentrations significantly decreased with increasing soil depth, measuring 0•9-1•2% in the topsoil (Figure 2 ) and 0•2-0•5% below 60 cm. Testing the depth factor separately for each system showed a significant decrease in SOC over soil depth in intercropping systems. The depth effect was statistically insignificant for intensely managed plantations and associated cropland because of the high SOC variability observed in these sites. Living fences with their associated cropland sites, afforestation systems, and particularly contour hedges showed statistically insignificant variations in SOC concentration over sampled soil depths. The virtually constant SOC concentrations over the entire soil depth under contour hedges and stone lines indicate steady C stocks. SOC stocks to a depth of 80 cm in soils under contour hedges were higher than those in the other plantation systems, whereas the topsoil values were the lowest among the studied systems (Figure 2 ).

All recently established J. curcas sites showed somewhat lower SOC concentrations than the adjacent cropland. In contrast, SOC concentrations in mature living fences (15 and 20 years old) significantly exceeded those in the reference cropping sites, indicating C accrual following J. curcas planting.

Significant differences were detected among the systems for SOC concentrations in the top 20-cm soil layer (Figure 2 ). Contour hedges had significantly lower SOC values (0•61 ± 0•08) than living fences (1•19 ± 0•08) and afforestation sites (1•08 ± 0•11). Given the differences in soil types among these systems, the observed variations have to be at least partly attributed to the location-specific soil properties. Among the cropland sites (pooled for each corresponding J. curcas system), no significant differences were observed (1•01 ± 0•10), although croplands associated with the intercropping and intensely managed plantations showed mean SOC concentrations at least 1•5 times higher than those adjacent to living fences and contour hedges. Below the 20-cm soil depth, variations among the systems were not significant.

The SOC expressed in mass per unit area (kg m À2 ) for the top 20-cm soil layer is shown in Figure 3 [FIGREF0: FIGURE 3 Figure 3. Mean values and their confidence intervals (95%) of (a) total soil organic carbon stocks (SOC) in mass per unit area (kg m À2 ) and (b) in equivalent soil mass (Equivalent SOC) in the topsoil (0-20 cm) of paired J. curcas and cropping sites (J. curcas systems: IC -Intercropping system; LV -Living fence; CH -Contour hedge; AF -Afforestation system; IM -Intensely managed plantation).] . Living fences exhibited significantly higher SOC masses than all the other systems (p < 0•001), except intensely managed plantations. Among the reference sites, significant differences were only observed between sites next to living fences and contour hedges (p < 0•05). Calculating SOC according to the equivalent soil mass of 28 g cm À2 for the first 20-cm increment resulted in more homogeneous SOC among J. curcas systems. Only contour hedges still showed the lowest values (p < 0•05). SOC masses in intercropping and afforestation systems increased following the calculation of the equivalent soil mass because of high gravel content and, consequently, low density of these soils.

In agreement with the results on SOC concentrations, SOC mass of cropland soils was also higher than that in J. curcas plantations in all paired sites, except for living fences. The C decline following afforestation in the first years is commonly observed and explained by the soil disturbance during plantation establishment and a fast mineralization of the fresh litter (Epron et al., 2009; Laganière et al., 2010) . In the afforestation systems, most J. curcas trees died in the first years after planting because of soil constraints and lack of management. Hence, the relatively high SOC stocks observed in these sites (Figure 3 [FIGREF0: FIGURE 3 Figure 3. Mean values and their confidence intervals (95%) of (a) total soil organic carbon stocks (SOC) in mass per unit area (kg m À2 ) and (b) in equivalent soil mass (Equivalent SOC) in the topsoil (0-20 cm) of paired J. curcas and cropping sites (J. curcas systems: IC -Intercropping system; LV -Living fence; CH -Contour hedge; AF -Afforestation system; IM -Intensely managed plantation).] ) are more because of the contribution by the fallow vegetation and the absence of soil tillage.

The construction of chronosequences for newly introduced J. curcas plantation systems did not reveal a clear SOC trend over 4 years. For some paired sites in the intercropping systems and intensely managed plantations, croplands showed higher SOC masses (p < 0•05) in the first 40-cm layer (Figure 3 [FIGREF0: FIGURE 3 Figure 3. Mean values and their confidence intervals (95%) of (a) total soil organic carbon stocks (SOC) in mass per unit area (kg m À2 ) and (b) in equivalent soil mass (Equivalent SOC) in the topsoil (0-20 cm) of paired J. curcas and cropping sites (J. curcas systems: IC -Intercropping system; LV -Living fence; CH -Contour hedge; AF -Afforestation system; IM -Intensely managed plantation).] ). Over all systems and sites, no differences between SOC stocks measured in 2010 and in 2011 were observed. These observations comply with the meta-analysis by Li et al. (2012) indicating significant C stock changes only after 30 years following afforestation. C decline in the first years since afforestation is commonly observed and explained by the soil disturbance during plantation establishment and a fast mineralization of the fresh litter (Epron et al., 2009; Li et al., 2012) .

In contrast, the chronosequence consisting of cropland soil (0 years) and living fences aged 15 and 20 years showed significant but low linear correlation between SOC (R 2 = 0•38, p < 0•05) and living fence age in the top 20 cm. In deeper soil layers, no significant SOC stock increase over time was observed. SOC concentrations exhibited patterns similar to those of SOC stocks (Figure 4 [FIGREF1: FIGURE 4 Figure 4. Linear regression and observed data points of total soil organic carbon (SOC, kg m À2 ) stocks in the topsoil (0-20 cm) in Jatropha curcas living fences in the central region of Burkina Faso. Dotted lines indicate confidence interval (95%).] ). The SOC masses of the cropping sites averaged 2•7 kg m À2 and increased to approximately 4•0 kg m À2 under mature living fences. The linear relationship for the 0-20 cm soil layers corresponds to an SOC accumulation rate of 62 ± 23 g C m À2 y À1 . The increase was the highest for the top 10-cm soil layer. Expressed in SOC concentration, an annual 0•02% increase from the initial 0•84% resulted in an SOC of 1•2%. Assuming soil coverage of 1200 m 2 by living fences (400-m hedge fencing 1 ha with a mean width of 3 m), an SOC sequestration of 77 kg ha À1 y À1 can be expected. Over the period of 20 years, this accumulates to 1•5 t C ha À1 . With 6•3 Mg C ha À1 sequestered in the woody above-ground and below-ground biomass of J. curcas living fences over 20 years (Baumert, 2014) , the contribution of topsoil SOC sequestration to the total ecosystem C accrual was 19%. In comparison with annual cropping systems, such as maize and cotton where usually only the root biomass of ~0•2-0•3 Mg C ha À1 (Tiessen et al., 1998) remains in the soil, J. curcas systems have substantial returns of organic material to the soil through the annual leaf fall. In general, in perennial systems with less soil disturbance, organic matter decomposition is slowed down. Eventually, high litterfall rates coupled with low decay rates lead to increasing litter stocks (Martius et al., 2004) and soil-C sequestration over time (Lal, 2004) . The observed increase in SOC of living fence systems is in line with the findings of Soulama (2008) that show an SOC mass increase in the 0-20 cm topsoil layer from 2•3 kg m À2 in a cropping site to 3•7 kg m À2 under a mature J. curcas living fence in the northern region of Burkina Faso. The observed values are high compared with the rates reported in the literature, for example, a global average accumulation of 33•8 g C m À2 y À1 in forests (Post & Kwon, 2000) , 10-20 g C m À2 y À1 in Senegal under best management practices (Batjes, 2001) , and 20-40 g C m À2 y À1 in arid and semi-arid agroforestry systems according to the literature review by Nair et al. (2009) . The findings of a metaanalysis by Guo & Gifford (2002) showed that land-use conversion from crop to plantation might cause a soil-C stock increase of 18% (estimated at 26% by Laganière et al., 2010) . This is substantially below the value of 48% calculated for the presented case. However, the high value can be explained given the localized planting with dense spacing in J. curcas living fences (<1-m distance between trees). Even though the share of SOC accumulation in the total C sequestration potential of living fences was high (19% over a growing period of 20 years), soil C sequestration in dry lands plays a negligible role in reducing the global C emission gap till 2100 (Batjes, 2001; Smith, 2008) . The incentive for J. curcas management leading to increasing SOC should therefore rather be seen in raising site productivity and soil fertility.

The 13 C natural abundance technique revealed subtle shifts in SOC stocks that would be significant in the long term but that might not be detected by less sensitive, conventional methodologies of total SOC measurements (del Galdo et al., 2003) . However, consistent with the results on SOC content in paired J. curcas and cropping sites in recently introduced J. curcas plantations, the δ 13 C signature of young J. curcas stands did not show significant amounts of newly C 3 -derived soil C (Table II ). The observed shift of the δ 13 C signature to significantly lower negative values in the intercropping systems can probably be traced back to a thick weed (C 4 ) cover in the plantations. As weed can be a major source of soil organic matter and seasonal shifts in weed composition (proportion of C 3 and C 4 weeds) can occur, monitoring of the weed component would help to better understand the soil C contribution by trees (Diels et al., 2001) .

In traditional living fences with mature J. curcas plants, the δ 13 C values in 0-20 cm topsoil were more negative than in the adjacent sorghum fields, indicating a contribution of J. curcas to soil C. The newly C 3 -derived C amounted to 10% (f new ) of SOC and eventually contributed to the significant increase in SOC. The proportion of C 3 -C was particularly high in the first 0-10 cm soil layer. In a sparse plantation of >15-year-old J. curcas trees where a young J. curcas intercropping system was integrated (sampling site 11, Appendix S1), parkland trees and ancient C 3 vegetation most likely contributed to the highly negative 13 C values observed (Table II ). However, despite the observable trends, the overall analyses did not prove significant differences in δ 13 C values between the mature J. curcas and the neighboring sorghum sites.

Statistically significant SOC accumulation over time could be observed solely in living fences, as these are the only systems existing over a long enough period in Burkina Faso.

The chronosequence study (covering 20 years) showed an average annual SOC accumulation of 62 g m À2 in the top 20 cm (48% increase over 20 years) under J. curcas living fences. This value was corroborated by observable changes in δ 13 C values, indicating a contribution of C 3 -derived C to total soil C. Even if no increase in SOC in the newly introduced J. curcas plantation systems could be discovered over the first years, long-term SOC accumulation can be expected on the basis of the high organic matter inputs through annual foliage deposition in contrast to annually harvested crop biomass. Longer-term measurements comprising standard soil analyses and 13 C natural isotope abundance should be undertaken in growing J. curcas plantations to investigate SOC changes over time. The equivalent soil mass approach is advisable for calculating SOC stock changes as the soils are characterized by high gravel content.

In J. curcas living fences, localized plantings with high tree densities, high litter production, and low soil disturbance led to comparably high soil C sequestration rates. These made an important contribution to the total C budget of the living fences. Thus, ignoring SOC changes would lead to an underestimation of the C sequestration potential. Although the contribution to climate change mitigation remains small from the global perspective, the observed SOC increases are locally important for enhancing soil productivity.

title: The potential of alley cropping in improvement of cultivation systems in the high rainfall areas of Zambia. III. Effects on soil chemical and physical properties
text:
A detailed study of the soil chemical and physical properties in seven-year-old alley cropping trial containing Leucaena leucocephala and Flemingia congesta in Northern Zambia is described. There was a strong correlation between the maize yield and the total amount of nitrogen applied, both from prunings and fertiliser, suggesting that a major reason for the observed benefit from alley cropping, particularly with Leucaena, was due to an improvement in nitrogen supply. Leucaena produced significantly more biomass, and its leaves had higher concentrations of nitrogen, phosphorous and potassium and lower C/N and C/P ratios than did those of Flemingia. There was also evidence that the trees had a beneficial effect on other soil chemical properties; under the hedgerows, particularly those of Leucaena, there were higher levels of organic carbon, Mg, K and ECEC, and pH values were also highest. It is suggested that higher levels of organic carbon in the alley crop treatments were responsible for the improvements observed in soil physical properties. Lower bulk density, lower penetration resistance, and a higher infiltration rate and pore volume fraction were measured in the alley crops, although there was no significant change in the soil water release parameters. A deteriorating effect of constant applications of nitrogen fertiliser on soil fertility was observed; as the level of urea application increased, there were significant decreases in Mg, K and pH, increases in A1 and soil acidity, and higher penetrometer resistance. These results highlight the urgent need for further research on biological methods of maintaining soil fertility. In Northern Zambia, government policy in the last decade has promoted maize production by the small-scale farming sector through the use of hybrid varieties and imported fertiliser, both heavily subsidised by donors [Stromgaard, 1984] . However, reduction of these subsidies in 1990 caused many small-scale farmers, unable to afford inputs, to return to the traditional chitemene and fundikila systems of cultivation. Evidence is also emerging that maize yields are declining despite increased rates of fertiliser application. A possible explanation suggested for this is soil acidification by the fertiliser [Bolt and Holdsworth, 1987] . For these reasons, if maize production is to be sustained in the region, alternative methods of maintaining soil fertility other than the sole use of fertiliser need to be developed. Alley cropping was suggested as one possible solution to the problem, and research began in 1984 at Misamfu Regional Research Station, Kasama, to assess its potential. Previous papers in this series have described the results from a number of trials evaluating the potential of alley cropping to maintain soil fertility in both maize production systems as well as the traditional chitemene and fundikila systems that may include maize during their cropping cycle [Matthews et al., 1991 [Matthews et al., , 1992a [Matthews et al., , 1992b]] . Results so far have not been encouraging; most trials showed a decline in crop yields in the alley cropping treatments after four years. It was suggested that this was a result of low tree biomass production, poor litter quality resulting in slow decomposition and nutrient release, and an inappropriate cropping sequence. However, in one trial lasting six years, it was found that Leucaena leucocephala, and to some extent Flemingia congesta, 1 consistently increased maize yields above the control treatment after initial amelioration of soil pH by liming [Matthews et al., 1992b] However, no significant changes in major soil chemical properties after six years of alley cropping could be measured, raising the question of how these yield increases were obtained. This paper describes the results of a detailed study of the soil chemical and physical properties of the trial in its seventh year, with the aim of identifying factors contributing to the maize yield improvements by Leucaena leucocephala and Flemingia congesta. The trial (trial D31 in Matthews et al. [1992b] ) was located at Misamfu Regional Research Station, Northern Province, Zambia (10~ 31~ 1536 m above sea level). The mean annual rainfall is 1360 mm, falling between November and April, with mean monthly temperatures ranging from 18 ~ to 23 ~ Pan evaporation varies from 5 mm d -1 to 8 mm d -1. The soil, classified as an Orthic Ferralsol, is strongly leached and of low inherent fertility. Fuller details of climate and soil are given in Matthews et al. The trial was established in 1984 as a split-plot design with four replicates. There were four main plot treatments (crop only, Leucaena leucocephala + crop, Sesbania sesban + crop, and Gliricidia sepium -tcrop) and three subplot treatments (0, 60 and 120 kg ha -1 N). Flemingia congesta replaced Sesbania in the second year due to the inability of the latter to withstand repeated pruning. Sub-plot size was 8 x 12 m, each containing four hedge-rows. Further details of the experimental design and management in the first six years (1984/85--1989/90 ) are given in Matthews et al. [1992b] . The current study was conducted during the 1990/91 growing season, and measurements were confined to the 'no trees', Leucaena, and Flemingia treatments, and replications I, III and IV. Although soybean was also planted in the trial, only the data for maize are presented. On December 17, 1990, the trees were pruned to 40 cm height and the prunings incorporated into ridges at a spacing of 1 m. Maize (var. MM604) was sown into the ridges on December 19. Single superphosphate (SSP) and KC1 were appfied on January 21 at rates of 200 kg ha -1 and 40 kg ha -1 (17 and 20 kg ha -1 P and K, respectively) as a band along one side of the tree and crop rows and covered with soil afterwards. Nitrogen, as the sub-plot treatment, was applied in the form of urea only to the maize in two split doses, the first on January 21 and the second three weeks later. The urea was also applied by banding but on both sides of each maize row. A second pruning was made on January 30. Biomass production at each pruning was measured in the same way as that described in Matthews et al. [1992@ The maize was harvested on May 13, the cobs were allowed to dry in the sun, and shelled. A sub-sample of around 100 g was taken for dry matter determination; these were weighed, dried in an oven at 105 ~ for 24 h, weighed again, and the original sample corrected to 12% moisture content. Leaf samples were taken from the maize, Leucaena, and Flemingia at all levels of N fertilization twice during the growing season. Samples from the trees were collected at the time of the two prunings. Four trees were selected at positions, 3, 9, 15, and 21 from one end of each of the four rows in each plot, and the last fully-developed leaves from the two highest shoots were taken. Thus, the composite sample from each plot contained 32 leaves from 16 trees. Maize leaves were sampled on January 29 and March 15. Leaves were taken from four plants in each of the outer rows, with the same spacing as for the tree samples, and from eight plants in each of the two middle rows in each plot, again giving 16 leaves in each composite sample. In the 'no trees' plots, one representative sample was made of leaves from all six rows in each plot. At the first sampling, the uppermost fully-developed leaf below the whorl was collected, while for the second sampling (at the tasselling stage), the leaf immediately below the lowest cobs was taken. If no cobs had developed, leaves were taken from the sixth leaf from the bottom. This was only the case in the 'no fertiliser/no trees' treatment. Leaves were taken from different plants at each sampling. All leaf samples were analysed at the chemical analytical laboratory at the Agricultural University of Norway. The nitrogen level was determined by Kjeldahl digestion, and P and K in the digested solution were measured by ICP. For C/N ratios, C and N contents were measured by infrared detection and thermal conductivity at 950 ~ for six composite samples from the Leucaena and Flemingia at the three N levels. Soil samples for chemical analysis were collected four times during the growing season (December 11, January 29, March 3, and May 24) using a standard 10 cm soil corer. Samples were collected from the furrows on either side of the middle maize row (defined as the 'M' position) at the 0--20 cm depth, and from the furrows between the hedgerows and the closest maize row (defined as the 'H' position) at 0--20 cm and 20--40 cm depths. Composite samples were made out of soil from two to three core holes for each position of the samples taken in December. In January, March and May, each sample consisted of soil from eight core holes. The holes were made at 1 and 5 m from the end at one side of the row, and with the same distance from the other end on the corresponding side. Samples were taken at least 30 cm from the core holes of the previous sampling to avoid interference of increased water and particle transport through the holes. A total of 63 composite samples were collected at each sampling date. With the exception of the December sampling, subsamples were taken from each fresh sample, placed in polythene bags, frozen, and sent for analysis of NO;-and NH + to Mt Makulu Central Research Station, Lusaka. The remainders of each sample were air dried, sieved through a 2 mm sieve, and placed in polythene bags prior to analysis at Misamfu. Methods of analysis of available Ca, Mg, K, P, soil pH, total N, organic C, and the effective cation exchange capacity (ECEC) are described in Matthews et al. [1992@ Soil mineral N was extracted with KC1; the NO3 content was analysed by reduction to nitrite by cadmium, and NH4 + by gas diffusion through a membrane into an indicator stream. The resulting color changes were measured by spectrophotometer. In January, penetrometer measurements were made in the 'no trees' and Leucaena plots in the 0 and 60 kg ha -~ N treatments. A cone penetrometer [Klute, 1986] fitted with a No. 3 cone (3.5 cm 2) was used, although occasionally it was found necessary to use a No. 2 cone (2 cm 2) when the soil was very hard. In each furrow, four measurements were made at positions 0.5, 2.5, 4.5, and 6.5 m from each end of the row. In each plot, sixteen penetrations were made in the outer rows and sixteen in the middle rows, and readings taken from 0--10, 10--20, 20--40, 40--60, 60--80, and 80--100 cm depths in the soil profile. After the maize harvest, soil samples were collected from 5--50 cm depth for determination of bulk density, pore volume fraction, and the parameters of the soil water retention curve (pF). These were taken only from the 'no trees' and Leucaena treatments, both without N fertiliser. Using 100 cc cylinders, four samples were collected from the middle rows and four from the outer rows, at positions 1.5, 3.5, 4.5, and 6.5 m from the end of the row. The cylinders were taken to Mt Makulu Central Research Station, Lusaka, for analysis. Water retention capacity was measured at tensions of 0.0, 0.033, 0.1 and 1.5 MPa using a pressure plate apparatus [Klute, 1986] . Values for the parameters a and b of the soil water retention curve In U s = a + b In | where U s is the soil water potential (MPa) and O s is the soil water content (%w/w), were obtained by fitting a straight line to the natural logarithmic transforms of each variable [Rogowski, 1972] . Bulk density and total porosity were also measured using the methods described in Klute [1986] . Infiltration rate measurements were made after the final harvest in the sole maize and Leucaena plots without N ferfiliser. Two holes, approximately 25 x 25 • 25 cm in size were made in each plot, at positions 1.5, 2.5, 4.5 and 6.5 m from the end of one row. The holes were filled with water to a depth of 15 cm, and the lowering of the water level measured at one minute intervals over a period of ten minutes. The process was repeated twice. The infiltration rate was calculated using the falling head method [Hvorslev, 1952] modified for use above the groundwater level. In comparison to Flerningia, Leucaena contributed considerably more N, not only by producing higher levels of biomass, but also by having a higher level of N in this biomass. The data in Table 3 indicate that there was a net increase of around 32 kg ha -* in the level of soil mineral N to a depth of 40 cm, mainly in the form of NH +, with no significant differences between either tree species, N treatments, or sampling positions. In addition to improved nitrogen supply, an equally important effect of Leucaena alley cropping seems to be the improvement of soil organic matter levels. Similar increases in organic carbon were found when the results of several alley cropping trails at the same site were averaged [Matthews et al., 1991] . The role of organic materials in improving soil physical, chemical and biological properties has been well reviewed in recent years [e.g. Allison, 1973] , and various studies have shown the beneficial effects of alley cropping on soil organic matter levels. For example, Kang et al. [1981 Kang et al. [ , 1985] ] and Kang and Wilson [1987] , in a trial lasting six years in Nigeria, observed that soil organic matter levels were maintained in the alley cropping plots, but declined in the control plots. Similarly, Handawela [1986] reported higher soil organic matter and nitrogen levels under Gliricidia maculatum alley crops in Sri Lanka than under maize only. Yamoah et al. [1986b] found that there was an improvement in soil organic matter levels in Cassia and Gliricidia alley crops compared to the control plots. This improvement occurred even when the prunings were not applied, suggesting a contribution from root residues. The beneficial effect of organic matter on soil physical properties is due in part to the action of organic gums in binding soil particles into aggregates, leading to an improvement in soil structure with a balanced distribution of pore sizes. This contributes to improved permeability and aeration, and easier root penetration, and in turn provides favourable conditions for development of fine feeder roots and mychorrhizae, so increasing the efficiency of nutrient uptake. The effects of improved soil physical properties on crop yields have been well reviewed by Lal and Greenland [1979] . As Yamoah et al. [1986a] have pointed out, good physical properties may even be more important than the supply of nutrients; the nutrients released from prunings become useless if the physical conditions do not favour proper root development to take up these nutrients. The present study showed significant reductions in soil bulk density, increases in the pore volume fraction and infiltration rates, and lower penetration resistance in the Leucaena treatments. Simlar results are emerging from other alley cropping studies. Handawela [1986] measured lower soil compression strengths under a Gliricidia maculatum alley crop in Sri Lanka, while Yamoah et al. [1986b] found a decrease in bulk density under alley crops of Gliricidia, Flemingia and Leucaena in Nigeria. Hulugalle and Kang [1990] , and Kang and Ghuman [1989] have observed similar improvements in soil physical proper-ties under various alley crops. Lal [1989b Lal [ , 1989c] ] reported that, despite an increase in bulk density and penetration resistance and a decrease in infiltration rates in all treatments, the rate of deterioration of these properties was less in Leucaena leucocephala and Gliricidia sepiurn alley crop treatments, particularly the former. This was attributed to effects on soil structure and structural porosity. The increased moisture retention capacity of the topsoil found by several authors [e.g. Kang et al., 1985; Yamoah et al., 1986b; Lal, 1989b] was not found in the present work. The effect of enhanced organic matter levels on soil chemical properties has also been well documented. Factors such as a balanced nutrient supply, a slow release of nutrients, protection from leaching, and a buffering effect against soil acidity have all been cited [Young, 1989] . Certainly, in the present work, there were higher levels of Mg, K and overall ECEC, and pH values were also highest, under the hedgerows (particularly Leucaena) where organic carbon levels were the highest. Similar trends were reported by Kang et al. [1981 Kang et al. [ , 1985]] . Various other authors have also found evidence of an amelioration of A1 and acidity buildup by alley crops [e.g. Lal, 1989 @ Young [1989] has argued that it is unlikely that alley cropping can raise pH on naturally acid soils, but that further acidification may be checked by increasing the concentration of Ca and other bases in leaves brought up from the lower layers and recycled to the surface. The higher levels of Mg, K and ECEC in the alley crop treatments in the present study suggest that this may be occurring. The higher nutrient content and lower acidity of the soil directly under the hedgerows suggests that litter fall and root residues are important factors contributing to soil fertility maintainance. Lal [1989b] also found lower soil bulk densities nearer the hedgerows, which he ascribed to enhanced earthworm activity and lack of soil disturbance. Nevertheless, despite the more favourable soil conditions, crop yields were significantly less closer to the tree rows [Matthews et al., 1991] , indicating that competition for light and possibly water may be more important than soil conditions. The detrimental effect of constant applications of nitrogenous fertiliser is highlighted by these results. Significant decreases in Mg and K (and to some extent, Ca), increases in A1 and soil acidity, and higher penetrometer resistance were evident as more urea was applied. Lal [1989a] has pointed out that Ca, Mg, and K are often replaced by AP + under continuous cropping. Bolt and Holdsworth [1987] have reported a decline in maize yields in Northern Province, Zambia, despite increasing rates of fertiliser application, suggesting a deterioration in soil fertility as a possible reason. Certainly, urea is known to have an acidifying effect on soils [Mengel and Kirkby, 1987] . The decline in Ca, Mg, and K with higher fertiliser applications may have been due to the increase in maize yield removing more of these nutrients, emphasising the importance of balanced fertiliser applications. Adequate supply of one nutrient only may result in an induced deficiency of others. Thus, although the high yields obtained with nitrogenous fertiliser application could not be obtained with alley cropping, the gradual deterioration in soil fertility, particularly in soil acidity, by the former, would seem to be a powerful argument in favor of continued research on alley cropping as a means of maintaining soil fertility and crop yields. While it is essential that other tree species should be screened for their ability to produce high quantities of biomass in the region, future research should also not discard Leucaena as a potential alley cropping species. Although the use of large quantities of lime is impractical at present for small-scale farmers in Northern Zambia IMatthews et al, 1992b] , the results from this trial have shown that Leucaena Ieucocephala seems to need favourable pH conditions only to establish; subsequent growth continues with no further applications even with soil pH as low as 4.4. It might be possible, therefore, to develop techniques of applying lime only to the soil around the seed or seedling, thereby reducing the quantities of lime required.

title: Long-term soil organic carbon dynamics in a subhumid tropical climate: 13 C data in mixed C 3 /C 4 cropping and modeling with ROTHC
text:
Scanty information on long-term soil organic carbon (SOC) dynamics hampers validation of SOC models in the tropics. We observed SOC content changes in a 16-year continuously cropped agroforestry experiment in Ibadan, south-western Nigeria. SOC levels declined in all treatments. The decline was most pronounced in the no-tree control treatments with continuous maize and cowpea cropping, where SOC levels dropped from the initial 15.4 to 7.3-8.0 Mg C ha 21 in the 0 -12 cm topsoil in 16 years. In the two continuously cropped alley cropping (AC) systems, one with Leucaena leucocephala and one with Senna siamea trees, SOC levels dropped to 10.7-13.2 Mg C ha 21 . Compared to the no-tree control treatments, an annual application of an additional 8.5 Mg ha 21 (dry matter) of plant residues, mainly tree prunings, led to an extra 3.5 Mg C ha 21 (,0.2% C) in the 0 -12 cm top soil after 11 years, and 4.1 Mg C ha 21 after 16 years. The addition of NPK fertilizer had little effect on the quantities of above-ground plant residues returned to the soil, and there was no evidence that the fertilizer affected the rate of SOC decomposition. The fact that both C 3 and C 4 plants returned organic matter to the soil in all cropping systems, but in contrasting proportions, led to clear contrasts in the 13 C abundance in the SOC. This 13 C information, together with the measured SOC contents, was used to test the ROTHC model. Decomposition was very fast, illustrated by the fact that we had to double all decomposition rate constants in the model in order to simulate the measured contrasts in SOC contents and d 13 C between the AC treatments and the no-tree controls. We hypothesized (1) that the pruning materials from the legume trees and/or the extra rhizodeposition from the tree roots in the AC treatments accelerated the decomposition of the SOC present at the start of the experiment (true C-priming), and/or (2) that the physical protection of microbial biomass and metabolites by the clay fraction on this site, having a sandy top soil in which clay minerals are mainly of the 1:1 type, is lower than assumed by the model.

Improved prediction of long-term changes of soil organic matter (SOM) contents in tropical soils should help identify more intensive and productive sustainable cropping systems. Because of the contribution of SOM to CEC, buffering capacity, soil structure, and water holding capacity, higher SOM levels could raise efficiencies of mineral fertilizers. A better understanding of long-term SOM dynamics can therefore significantly contribute to the current renewed research on the benefits of combining synthetic and organic sources of plant nutrients. Improved predictive capabilities moreover would allow for more precise assessment of the carbon sequestration potential in tropical soils.

SOM models, if properly validated against long-term data, offer the possibility of estimating changes in SOM levels under current and improved cropping systems without initiating new long-term experiments. Unfortunately, only a limited number of studies (Woomer, 1993; Parton et al., 1994; Myers, 1995; Vallis et al., 1996; Smith et al., 2000; Gijsman et al., 2002) have tested SOM models against longterm data from tropical regions. Most if not all SOM models were developed using long-term data from temperate regions only. The particular mineralogy of many tropical soils and the lack of understanding of its influence on SOM stabilization (Merckx et al., 2001) , underscores the need for model validation using long-term data from the tropics, a task which is hampered by the limited availability of welldocumented long-term experiments.

Various types of experimental data have been used to test SOM models for temperate and tropical regions: (1) time series of soil organic carbon (SOC) contents (Jenkinson et al., 1994; Parton and Rasmussen, 1994; Vallis et al., 1996) , and ( 2) SOC contents at one particular time in sites/treatments which differ in one or another factor controlling SOC levels (such as quantity or type of the organic materials returned to the soil) (Parton et al., 1987; Paustian et al., 1992) .

Many studies have used the 13 C natural abundance technique to generate quantitative information on long-term SOM dynamics in temperate and tropical regions (e.g. Martin et al., 1990; Veldkamp, 1994; Feigl et al., 1995; Hsieh, 1996) . The method, developed by Cerri et al. (1985) , is based on the fact that plants with a C 3 photosynthetic pathway have a 13 C abundance ranging between 2 24 and 2 34‰, while C 4 plants range between 2 6 and 2 19‰ (Smith and Epstein, 1971) . Because the 13 C abundance of incoming plant material is largely preserved during mineralization and humus formation, the 13 C content of the SOC reflects the 13 C content of the vegetation. If a change occurred from a C 3 to a C 4 vegetation or vice versa at a known time in the past, it is possible to infer the turnover time of the SOC originating from the first vegetation type from the present 13 C content of the SOM.

The possibility of using carbon isotope data as additional information for testing SOM models has been known since the work by Jenkinson et al. (1992) on changes in soil 14 C content following the nuclear tests in the early 1960s. However, very few researchers (Balesdent, 1996; Molina et al., 2001) have used 13 C abundance data in combination with SOM models. The use of the 13 C technique moreover has been limited to complete transitions from pure C 3 to pure C 4 vegetation (or vice versa). Tropical agroecosystems often involve a mixture or rotation of C 3 and C 4 plants.

The objectives of our study were to (1) monitor SOC changes on a 16-year time scale in a field experiment under sub-humid tropical conditions involving treatments with mixtures of C 3 and C 4 plants, (2) investigate the usefulness of the 13 C tracer technique for such a mixed C 3 -C 4 situation, and (3) use the experimental data to test the ROTHC SOM model (Jenkinson, 1990; Coleman and Jenkinson, 1995) .

A field experiment was established in 1986 to compare a Leucaena leucocephala and a Senna siamea alley cropping (AC) system with a control system without trees.

L. leucocephala is a fast-growing N-fixing legume tree, while S. siamea is a legume tree that does not fix N and grows less vigorously. Since 1986, the AC cropping systems and the control have been continuously cropped with maize during the first growing season (May -July) and cowpea during the second growing season (September -November), except for 1992 when the field was left fallow in the second season. The experiment was established on an Episkeleti-Ferric Lixisol (Chromic) (ISSS-FAO-ISRIC, 1998) on the experimental farm of the International Institute of Tropical Agriculture (IITA) in Ibadan, SW-Nigeria (7830 0 N, 3854 0 E). The experimental field had a 6% slope. Farm records indicated that between 1975 and 1981 the land has been used for annual crops (maize, cowpea), and left under grass fallow from 1982 to 1986. The plot of land is visible as arable land free of shrubs or trees on aerial photographs taken in 1975 and 1979. Prior to the establishment of the IITA experimental farm in 1967, the land has been used by smallholder farmers, who presumably practiced a bushfallow system. Ibadan has a bimodal rainfall, with an annual mean of 1278 mm, and a mean annual temperature of 26.2 8C. The trial was set up as a randomized complete block design with five replications and six treatments: the above-mentioned three cropping systems with and without fertilizer. The experimental plots measured 19.5 £ 10 m. Yearly additions of urea (120 kg N ha 21 ), single super phosphate (40 kg P ha 21 ) and muriate of potash (25 kg K ha 21 ) comprised the fertilizer treatments. From 1994 onwards, these levels were decreased to 60 kg N ha 21 , 16.2 kg P ha 21 , and 15 kg K ha 21 . The trees in the AC systems were planted 4.5 m between the rows and 0.5 m within the rows at the beginning of the growing season in 1986, first pruned in 1987, and then regularly pruned 3-4 times a year. Tree prunings, excluding woody stems . 10 mm, were left on the plots. Tillage consisted of loosening of 3-5 cm of topsoil with a hand hoe prior to planting and at each manual weeding operation. Weeds were managed with a combination of a single herbicide spraying before each maize and cowpea planting and subsequent manual weeding (3 -4 times during the first season, twice during the second season). All weed residues were left in the plots. At harvest, the maize and cowpea residues were left on the plots. The only exceptions were that the 1986 maize residues were removed from the plots that received NPK fertilizer, and that the 1988 and 1989 residues were redistributed between all plots to obtain the same application rate in all plots (3.59 Mg DM ha 21 in 1988 and 6.15 Mg DM ha 21 in 1989). Full details of the management of this long-term experiment are given by Van der Meersch et al. (1993) for the 1986 -1990 period and Vanlauwe et al. (2004) ) for the 1986 -2002 period.

The SOC content was expressed in Mg C ha 21 present in an equivalent soil mass of 1700 Mg ha 21 of mineral soil following the procedure outlined by Ellert and Bettany (1995) . Its equivalent thickness averaged 12 cm and varied slightly between sampling times and treatments due to bulk density differences. Bulk density values used in the calculations were derived from the same cores as used for the determination of the %C content to ensure consistency between %C and bulk density values used in the calculation procedure (Ellert et al., 2001) . Average d 13 C values were calculated likewise for the same equivalent soil mass.

The SOC contents and d 13 C values (1997 and 2002 data) were analyzed with a mixed-model ANOVA considering cropping system, fertilizer level, and their interaction as fixed effects and replicates (blocks) as a random effect (SAS Institute, 1992).

All crop and tree residue inputs were quantified throughout the experiment by weighing fresh residues on each plot and calculating the dry weight using the dry matter contents of subsamples (one sample taken per experimental plot). Carbon inputs (Mg C ha 21 ) were calculated using the measured average C contents of the respective plant residue types. Litter input from the roots in the top 12 cm were accounted for by multiplying (above-ground) residues of maize, cowpea and weeds by 1.10, Senna prunings biomass by 1.15 and Leucaena prunings biomass by 1.075. These factors were based on root:shoot ratios and information about variation of root density with depth reported by Jonsson et al. (1988) , Toky and Bisht (1992) , Schroth and Zech (1995) , Govindarajan et al. (1996), and Vanlauwe et al. (2002) . The factors do not account for root turnover, so true carbon inputs were likely slightly higher then estimated.

The area used for measuring the biomass production was the entire 19.5 £ 10 m plot for the tree prunings (four tree rows of 10 m length), and a smaller area for the maize stover (ranging from 6 £ 19.5 to 10 £ 19.5 m over the years). Cowpea residue input was quantified from 1993 onwards by measuring the aboveground biomass (excluding the pods) at the start of leaf senescence in one or two 0.5 £ 4 m frames per plot. Some biomass data are missing and were estimated. This was the case for the 1987 tree prunings and maize stover, the 1986 -1991 cowpea haulms, and the 2000 tree prunings. It was assumed that the biomass production of the Senna and Leucaena trees in 1987, i.e. the first year after establishment, amounted to 50% of the average yearly biomass production of 1989 -1991. The maize stover produced and applied in 1987 was taken as the average of the 1986 and 1988 production. As there were no data on the cowpea biomass yields for the years 1986-1991, the mean of the biomass measured for 1993-1997 was taken instead. The missing 2000 tree biomass was interpolated from the 1999 and 2001 data.

Weed biomass measurements were taken in 1988, 1989, and 1990 by collecting all above-ground weed biomass in a 4.0 £ 1.5 m area in the middle of each plot at the time of the weeding operations (six times per year). Another set of weed biomass observations was taken in 1998 -1999 using a 0.5 £ 4.15 m frame randomly positioned in each plot. Weed biomass production rapidly declined from 1988 to 1990 and stabilized thereafter, as indicated by the fact that weed biomass production in 1998 was very similar to that in 1990. The missing weed biomass information for 1986-1987 and 1991-1997 was therefore interpolated from the available data using a negative exponential relationship with time.

Ball-milled plant samples of weeds, cowpea haulms, maize stover, and tree prunings from a selected subset of years were analyzed for 13 C natural abundance, and results were expressed in d 13 C units using the same methods as for the soil samples. Analysis of variance, reported by Diels et al. (2001) revealed that year-to-year variation of d 13 C values for these plant residues was so small that the information obtained from the selected years is representative for the entire duration of the trial.

Changes in SOC levels and d 13 C were simulated using the ROTHC-26.3 model (Jenkinson, 1990; Coleman and Jenkinson, 1995) . ROTHC-26.3 is a model of the turnover of organic carbon in soils on a time scale of years to centuries. It allows for the effects of clay content, temperature, moisture content, and plant cover on decomposition. The model mimics decomposition by defining four active SOC compartments and a small inert compartment (IOM). The four active compartments are decomposable plant material (DPM), resistant plant material (RPM), microbial biomass (BIO), and humified organic matter (HUM). These four active compartments decompose following first-order kinetics, while the IOM compartment is resistant to decomposition. The effect of plant litter quality is handled by specifying how the carbon for a particular incoming material is split over the DPM and RPM compartments.

Long-term averages of monthly mean air temperature, rainfall, and open pan evaporation for Ibadan were given as inputs to the model. In line with the practiced cropping system, it was specified that the soil was covered by a crop from May to November and bare during the remaining 5 months. The topsoil clay content was set to the observed value (9%). The DPM:RPM ratio was set to 1.44 for the maize, cowpea, and weed residues and to 0.82 for the tree prunings. As prunings consist of woody twigs (, 10 mm diameter) and easily decomposable leaves, we choose a value (0.82) intermediate between the 1.44 value recommended for improved grassland and agricultural crops, and the 0.25 value for deciduous or tropical woodland (Jenkinson et al., 1992; Coleman and Jenkinson, 1995) . Three sets of simulation runs were made: one with all decomposition rate constants set to the values fixed by the model authors (Coleman and Jenkinson, 1995) ; one with the DPM:RPM ratio set to 2.33 instead of the above-mentioned 0.82 value and all other rate constants and parameters left unchanged; and a third one with all decomposition rate constants doubled and all other parameters as set by the model authors.

Through the work of Jenkinson and Ayanaba (1977) it is well known that SOC decomposition in the humid tropical Ibadan climate proceeds four times faster than under temperate conditions in Rothamsted, and this temperature effect is built into the ROTHC model. The fact that we nevertheless had to double the ROTHC rate constants to correctly reproduce the observed contrast in SOC contents and d 13 C values between the AC and control treatments means that turnover was very fast in this experiment, about eight times faster than in Rothamsted conditions.

Various factors could explain this seemingly fast decomposition. A first factor to consider is possible SOC loss by soil erosion, a process not accounted for by the ROTHC-26.3 model. In a 6-year trial with the same continuous maize/cowpea rotation on a nearby site with a similar coarse-sandy top soil and a slightly steeper slope (7%), Lal (1989) observed average soil losses of the order of 4.3 Mg ha 21 yr 21 for a plowed plot without trees, 0.1 Mg ha 21 yr 21 for a no-till plot without trees, and 0.57 Mg ha 21 yr 21 for a Leucaena AC system with 4 m wide alleys. Even the largest soil loss (4.3 Mg ha 21 yr 21 ) corresponds only to an apparent C decomposition rate of 0.007 yr 21 ( ¼ annual soil loss/soil mass in top 12 cm £ 2 £ 1.5, where 2 is the sediment enrichment factor and the factor 1.5 accounts for the fact that the %C in the top 5 cm is 50% higher than the C% in the 0 -12 cm soil). Given Lal's work, carbon losses through soil erosion must have been negligibly small compared to losses due to SOM decomposition.

Termite activity is another process that might explain the seemingly fast decomposition. Termites accelerate OM decomposition by comminution, but could also bury litter fragments in nests below the sampling depth or outside the plots. In an experiment in the same environment, Vanlauwe et al. (1998) observed that 15 N-labeled Dactyladenia barteri residues disappeared quickly from the surface litter layerfaster than observed in litterbags that excluded termites from the litter-without being recovered in the surface soil. Termite activity was suggested as a possible explanation. Termite activity on crop and tree residues was also observed in the present experiment, and could explain why the buildup of SOC in the surface layer was lower than expected. Yet little is known about the quantity of OM that termites can remove from the surface layer.

It is also possible that the mineral fertilizer or the legume tree prunings and/or rhizodeposition from the tree roots accelerated the turnover of SOM, and in this way reduced the difference in SOC levels between AC and control treatments. Such priming effects are not considered in the ROTHC-26.3 model, as is the case for most SOM models (Kuzyakov et al., 2000) . So the model predicted that the 'old' SOC decomposed at the same rate in all treatments, and we thus validated the model with this inherent assumption by comparing simulated and predicted contrasts of SOC contents and 13 C abundances between treatments. However, it cannot be excluded that the high-quality residues from the legume trees and/or rhizodeposition from the tree roots accelerated the turnover of the old C compared to the control plots. Some laboratory incubation studies with 13 C or 14 C labeled residues indicate that the addition of easily decomposable OM to soil might double or even triple the mineralization of the soil C (Broadbent, 1947; Vanlauwe et al., 1994; Liang et al., 1999) . In a field incubation study with soil sampled from the control plot in the Ibadan long-term experiment, it was indeed observed that several legume residue types increased the decomposition of the native SOC soil carbon (K. Oorts, PhD thesis 539, K.U. Leuven). Unfortunately, there is little information about the extent to which such C-priming occurs in the field in the longer term.

An underestimation of the rate of decomposition of the incoming plant litter during the experiment could possibly explain the differences between model and observations as well. The short-to-medium term (, 2 years) decomposition of incoming plant materials is strongly dependent on litter quality. That these legume tree prunings decompose relatively fast is expected from their high N content: 4.2 -5.3% for Leucaena and 2.7 -3.6% for Senna leaves (Vanlauwe et al., 1997) . The effect of litter quality is handled in the model by the choice of the magnitude of the DPM and RPM fractions in the plant material. We might have underestimated the decomposition rate of the tree prunings to some extent, but that does not explain all discrepancies between the model and the data, as was shown by the model run in which we increased the DPM:RPM ratio of the tree prunings from 0.82 to 2.33.

Another reason for the fast decomposition might be the low physical protection of SOM in this sandy topsoil (9% clay, predominantly kaolinite). The effect of physical protection by clay is accounted for in the model by making the partition between CO 2 evolved and (BIO þ HUM) formed during decomposition dependent on the inorganic cation exchange capacity (CEC min ) based on the relationship derived from observations over the first 10 days in Sørensen's (1975) laboratory experiment with labeled cellulose. Quantitative information on the effect of clay content and type (or CEC) on long-term SOC dynamics are, however, scarce and variable. Decomposition studies in the field with labeled residues demonstrated that retention after 8 years in southern Australia and after 10 years in England was between 5 and 40% higher in heavier textured soils than in lighter textured soils (Jenkinson, 1977; Ladd et al., 1985) . The part in the ROTHC model dealing with the later stages of decomposition has been parameterized exclusively on data from experiments in Rothamsted (Jenkinson et al., 1992) on sites having high-activity clays and fairly high clay contents. Therefore, underestimation of the textural control effect on SOM stabilization could explain why the model underestimates the SOC decomposition rate for this sandy topsoil in which clay minerals are mainly of the 1:1 type. If the textural control mechanism is indeed so much weaker in this soil, it would mean that SOM buildup is most difficult in those soils where SOM is most needed in order to attain sufficient cation exchange capacity.

The data from a 16-year field experiment in SW-Nigeria and modeling of the SOC dynamics during the trial using the ROTC26.3 model led to the following findings:

1. SOC levels declined in all treatments. The decline was most pronounced in the no-tree control treatments with continuous maize and cowpea cropping, where SOC levels dropped from the initial 15.4 to 7.3-8.0 Mg C ha 21 in 16 years (SOC content in 1700 Mg ha 21 equivalent soil mass). In the two continuously cropped AC systems (Leucaena and Senna), the SOC levels dropped to levels between 10.7 and 13.2 Mg C ha 21 . 2. The addition of mineral fertilizer (NPK) had little effect on the quantities of plant residues returned to the soil (sum of weeds, crop residues, and tree prunings), and there was no evidence that the fertilizer affected the rate of SOC decomposition. 3. The 13 C natural abundance technique yielded useful information to test SOM models in a complex cropping system, in which both C 3 and C 4 plants were intercropped/rotated, and contrasts in the d 13 C of the SOC resulted from the fact that the relative OM contribution of the C 3 and C 4 components differed between the treatments compared. 4. The fact that we had to double the decomposition rate constants of the ROTHC-26.3 model in order to reproduce the observed contrasts in SOC contents and 13 C abundance between the AC systems and the control without trees indicated that SOC decomposition in this experiment was very fast. Possible reasons for this are (1) that the pruning materials from the legume trees and/or the extra rhizodeposition from the tree roots in the AC treatments accelerated the decomposition of the SOC present at the start of the experiment (true C-priming), and/or (2) that the physical protection of microbial biomass and metabolites by the clay fraction in the sandy top soil, in which clay minerals are mainly of the 1:1 type, was lower than assumed by the model. Termite activity could also have contributed to the seemingly fast decomposition.
