Similar results have been previously reported (Thevathasan Fig. 3 Variation in mean soil organic carbon before planting and after harvesting maize over different distances from tree row on the east and west side of the line of trees for a control (bare soil), b Casuarina, c Grevillea, d Maesopsis and e Markhamia, over all soil depths in a linear simultaneous agroforestry system in Mukono District, Central Uganda Gordon 2004; Soto-Pinto et al. 2007) . A study on the tree intercropping systems in north temperate regions found that the C sequestration potential in hybrid-Liriodendron tulipifera intercropping system was four times higher than that of conventional agricultural fields in the region (Thevathasan and Gordon 2004) , while a comparison of corn fields to Taungya, tropical-improved fallow, sub-tropical improved fallow, coffee-tree system and traditional agroforestry systems concluded that agroforestry systems contained more SOC than the corn field (Soto-Pinto et al. 2007) . The higher SOC found in the agroforestry systems compared to maize crop or bareland may be attributed to incorporation of more litter fall from the trees (i.e., leaves, branches and twigs) into soil that adds organic matter and improves soil quality. Below-ground, tree roots penetrate to deeper soil layers than crop roots and bring nutrients to the surface via leaf fall (Schroeder 1993) . The success of the intercropping system depends mainly on the capacity of the system components to maximize resource utilization, while at same time maintaining complementary interactions among them (Thevathasan and Gordon 2004) . It has been noted that perennial woody plants may possess a greater potential to exploit the below-ground environment directly than seasonal plants because, over multiple years, the root systems of woody plants can grow incrementally or parts of the root systems can be replaced in situ from season to season, hence increasing nutrient capture (Huxley 1999) . In addition, multistrata agroforestry practices will contribute litter from a mixture of species, providing a better nutrient balance in the soil as compared to monocropping systems, hence increasing soil organic matter in form of litter and root matter (Ong et al. 1996) . Woody species in agroforestry are capable of having better spatial and temporal utilization of available growth resources than annual species. The structural attributes of agroforestry, such as multiple vertical strata, allow the system to occupy space efficiently and provide a range of growing conditions (Schroeder 1993 ). The tree canopy in an agroforestry system provides shade and reduces evaporation from the soil. This shading effect also reduces temperature and provides a more moderate microclimate for crop growth. The tree canopy also provides shelter from wind, protects the soil from the impacts of heavy rain and helps to reduce soil erosion. Leaf litter acts as mulch and reduces evaporation, surface runoff and erosion, hence protecting the topsoil, which has more soil organic carbon and other soil nutrients. Therefore, agroforestry systems have a greater potential to increase soil organic carbon compared to the bareland or crop only practices. These characteristics may make agroforestry systems more resistant to climate change than monocropping systems. Distance from the tree row did not significantly influence SOC concentration for the treatments in this study, although it has been found that total soil C within the hybrid (Poplar) Liriodendron tulipifera intercropping site was significantly higher at 1 and 2 m away from the tree row compared to the middle of the alley (Thevathasan 1998) . The results of this study are similar to previously reported research (Oelbermann and Voroney 2007; Peichl et al. 2006; Thevathasan and Gordon 2004) , in which no significant differences in the amount of SOC were found at varying distances from the line of trees. Thevathasan and Gordon (2004) reported that SOC did not change significantly in the three distance zones from crop trees (0-2.5, 3-8, 8-15 m) 6 to 8 years after tree planting. Furthermore, it was observed that 15 years after planting, Liriodendron tulipifera trees were 14 m tall and leaf biomass was evenly distributed across the crop alley to a distance of up to 15 m, which resulted in a slow increase in SOC in the middle of the crop alley (Thevathasan and Gordon 2004) . Oelbermann and Voroney (2007) noted that after 13 years of alley cropping with hybrid Liriodendron tulipifera, the SOC and N pools did not differ significantly with distance from the tree row, although a trend of a large SOC and N pool near the tree row was observed. Differences in SOC found between exotic and indigenous species may be due to the varying abilities of trees to capture soil nutrients, varying amounts of litter fall and root distribution, different rates of decomposition and other resources under different environments (Huxley 1999) . In addition, the amount of litterfall and differences in the litter decomposition rates among the different tree species may also influence SOC. The study conducted by Wajja-Musukwe et al. (2008) in Uganda at the same site, indicated that there were differences among the growth rates and form of the these tree species. Wajja-Musukwe et al. (2008) , also showed that there were significant differences between species in the mean number of main roots in the trench, were G. robusta had more main roots per tree than the other species, which could contribute the difference in SOC among the tree species. There was significant variation in SOC with soil depth, where more SOC was observed at 0-25 cm soil depth and the least amount was measured at 50-100 cm. This indicates that SOC decreases with increasing soil depth in the linear simultaneous agroforestry systems. This result may be related to the decrease in root numbers with increasing depth in the soil profile and distance from the tree row (Wajja-Musukwe et al. 2008) . This study also noted that the soil profile under M. eminii showed maximum number of roots at a depth of about 0.45 m, whereas roots of other species (C. equisetifolia, M. lutea, and.G robusta) were most numerous closer to the soil surface. A study on alley cropping with hybrid poplar (Liriodendron tulipifera) found that SOC and N were not evenly distributed throughout the plow layer but the largest C and N pools occurred in top 20 cm of the soil horizon, which was attributed to the recent adoption of conservation tillage and no-till promoting the accumulation of SOC and N (Oelbermann and Voroney 2007) . However, in this study decrease in SOC may be due to the decrease in the rate of activities (biological and physical) as soil depth increases. More still, the spatial pattern of organic carbon stocks has been observed to be controlled by the distribution of root litter and the sorption of dissolved organic carbon (DOC) in the depth increments (Scho ¨ning et al. 2006) . Therefore, low spatial variation of SOC at soil depth below 12 cm was attributed to the high small scale variability of pore distribution and distribution of aluminum and iron (Scho ¨ning et al. 2006) . When change in SOC between before planting and after harvesting was analyzed, results showed that there was a greater loss in SOC in the top 25 cm compared to the deeper soil depths. Factors known to cause a loss in SOC (such as precipitation, soil temperature, tilling, etc.) affect the top layers of the soil more than at deeper soil depths. Soil bulk density ranged from 0.49 to 2.38 Mg m -3 , with the average soil bulk density of the area was 1.69 Mg m -3 and standard deviation of 0.35 Mg m -3 . Soil bulk density varied significantly among the treatments and soil depth. The overall assessment of soil bulk density shows that mean soil bulk density increases with increasing soil depth and inversely with SOC, as has been previously observed (Don et al. 2007) . Although there was no significant direction effect in this study, our results indicate a significant interaction between direction and distance before planting maize. This implied that as the distance from the tree increases, changes in SOC are not the same in the east-west directions. For all the data sets, there was more SOC in the western direction (sunset) than the east (sunrise) for Casuarina equisetifolia, Markhamia lutea, and Grevillea robusta at distances of 7.5-12.5 m away from the tree row, whereas Maesopsis eminii plots had more SOC on the eastern side than the west for distances closer to the tree row (0-7.5 m). This could be due to the differences in orientation and size of the tree crown as well as the varying root architecture among the tree species. Overall SOC within 100 cm surface for all the trees species was higher than the control plot with no trees. This may be due to the presence of trees which contribute more leaves, forage and branch litter as well as the amount of roots that decompose as compared to control plots with trees only. However, the SOC (Mg C ha -1 ) values obtained under a linear agroforestry system in Uganda are relatively higher than those reported by others (e.g., Dixon 1995; Montagnini and Nair 2004; Mutuo et al. 2005; Winjum et al. 1992 ). This may be due to the factors such as species used and tree density (Dixon 1995; Montagnini and Nair 2004 ) that influences the potential of an agroforestry system to sequester carbon. Others factors that may influence the amount of SOC stored include agroforestry management practices, age of the trees and environmental factors. Although this is a baseline study, the results indicate that linear simultaneous agroforestry systems have significant potential to increase soil organic carbon compared to control plots with no trees or crop only. There was no significant difference in the amount of SOC among the exotic and indigenous tree species. Soil bulk density varied significantly among the treatments and with soil depth. Among the exotic species, Grevillea robusta had more SOC than Casuarina equisetifolia. There was a significant difference in SOC among the indigenous species, where Maesopsis eminii had more SOC than Markhamia lutea. There was more SOC in the western direction (sunset) than the east (sunrise) for Casuarina equisetifolia, Markhamia lutea, and Grevillea robusta treatments at distances far from the tree row, whereas Maesopsis eminii plots had more SOC on the eastern side than the west for distances close to the tree row. Distance from the tree row did not significantly influence soil organic carbon concentration for the treatments. In selecting a tree species to integrate with crops as well as sequestrating reasonable quantities of carbon, a farmer can either plant an exotic or an indigenous species. Among the treatments studied, integrating trees and crops have a higher potential to sequester carbon than crop only. In this study, Grevillea robusta and Maesopsis eminii have the highest potential to store organic carbon in the soil compared to other tree species. It is recommended that further studies be conducted to assess the changes in SOC over the long-term. AgroforestSyst (2012) 84:11-23
